block.p: South Korean Leader Hails A New Era With the North President Kim Dae Jung told jubilant South Koreans on his return from the Korean summit meeting in Pyongyang that ''a new day is beginning'' for the divided peoples.

Putin Criticizes Mogul's Arrest President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, visiting Berlin, said prosecutors went ''too far'' in jailing Vladimir A. Gusinsky, owner of Russia's largest independent media company.

South Korean Leader Hails A New Era With the North President Kim Dae Jung told jubilant South Koreans on his return from the Korean summit meeting in Pyongyang that ''a new day is beginning'' for the divided peoples.

Putin Criticizes Mogul's Arrest President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, visiting Berlin, said prosecutors went ''too far'' in jailing Vladimir A. Gusinsky, owner of Russia's largest independent media company.

Mr. Putin, speaking to German business leaders, proposed that his country be placed at the heart of Europe's defenses against missile attack and warned that an American missile defense system would lead to a ''very dangerous'' arms race.

Serb Opposition Leader Shot Vuk Draskovic, leader of the largest opposition party, was shot in the head by gunmen at his home in Montenegro, but the wounds were not serious and he was released from a hospital after treatment, an adviser said.

Arafat at White House President Clinton met with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to try to arrange a summit meeting with Israel, but an official said they did not resolve one important obstacle: Mr. Arafat's insistence that Israel proceed with the final withdrawal from West Bank land called for in the Oslo accords seven years ago.

Objections to Israeli Radar Sale American diplomats met with Israeli military officials to reiterate objections to the sale of an airborne radar system to China and to press for consultations before Israel offers advanced weapons to other countries ''of concern'' to the United States.
Ethiopia-Eritrea Fighting Eased Fighting between Ethiopian and Eritrean soldiers paused as ministers from both nations prepared to sign a preliminary cease-fire Sunday.
Diamonds, Drugs and War A World Bank study concluded that armed rebels around the world were more often motivated by the pursuit of commodities, like diamonds and drugs, than by intangible goals.

Gore Replaces Chairman Of Presidential Campaign Vice President Al Gore said Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, regarded as a shrewd operative in Democratic politics, would replace Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, Tony Coelho, who is hospitalized with an inflamed colon. Mr. Daley, a scion of the Chicago political family, will leave the cabinet on July 15. Though Mr. Coelho's departure was attributed to the advice of his doctors, many Democrats said the move was inevitable, given the way that Mr. Gore's campaign had been struggling.

Citing rising budget surplus estimates, Mr. Gore said he would offer Americans $500 billion in tax cuts over 10 years, twice what Mr. Gore had proposed and half of what his Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush had proposed. Gore aides said the tax cuts would primarily be limited to families with children and aging parents while Mr. Bush's would apply across the board.

Bush Plan for the Disabled Gov. George W. Bush proposed an additional $880 million in federal spending and tax incentives over five years to help disabled Americans with work, public access and new technology.

No Doubt on Murder Testimony Bernadine Skillern, the lone witness to identify Gary Graham as the killer in a Texas parking lot 19 years ago, came forward to repeat that she was certain that the right man had been convicted. Mr. Graham is to die on Thursday in a case that has drawn national attention and created a political headache for Gov. George W. Bush.

Appeal of Elian Ruling Lawyers for the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez asked all 12 judges of the federal appeals court based in Atlanta to reverse a decision that would allow the boy's father to take him back to Cuba.

Woods Holds Early Open Lead Tiger Woods shot a six-under par 65 to take the opening-round lead of the United States Open at Pebble Beach, Calif. But fog suspended play before all players could finish.

Lazio's First Stock Options Paid a Handsome Return Representative Rick A. Lazio's first foray into high-risk securities -- $2,300 for stock options on Quick & Reilly, a brokerage house, in August 1997 -- yielded $16,000 in less than two weeks, a nearly 600 percent gain, on word of a possible takeover. A spokesman said Mr. Lazio, who was in his third term at the time, bought shares in the company earlier and had simply made a shrewd bet.

More Arrests in Park Attacks The police arrested six more men in the sex attacks in Central Park after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday and identified more suspects in the frenzy of assaults that terrified parkgoers, embarrassed the city and prompted an internal police review. All told, eight men have been arrested in the assaults on dozens of women.
Patrick J. Buchanan, a Republican seeking the Reform Party nomination for president, suggested that ''liberal cop-bashing'' by Hillary Rodham Clinton and others had encouraged the park attacks.

Nile Virus Detected in Queens City health officials said initial tests had shown that a chicken left in a coop in Corona, Queens, had been infected with the West Nile virus, and that if follow-up tests confirmed that finding, insecticide would be sprayed in the area next week.

Dispute Over Rent Rise Tenants and landlords squared off at the Rent Guidelines Board's annual hearing over the city's proposal for the largest rent rise in four years. A final vote is set for Thursday.
Robert Trent Jones The golf architect who designed or remodeled more than 500 courses, and who once shot a hole in one to justify a hole's redesign, was 93.

C21 Robert J. Lurtsema The host of the public radio classical music program ''Morning Pro Musica,'' an announcer who was equally revered and reviled for his resonant timbre and slow, drawling delivery, was 68.

Ford Factory Most Efficient A study found the Ford Taurus factory in Atlanta the most efficient car plant in North America last year, representing the first time that an American-owned auto plant surpassed Japanese-owned factories on the continent in labor productivity.

New Company for Murdoch The News Corporation of Rupert Murdoch is preparing an S.E.C. filing to sell shares in a new company holding all the interests in satellite television that the company has been building up over the last decade.
Morgan Stanley Brokers' Chief Morgan Stanley Dean Witter chose John Schaefer, 48, an investment banker, to run its brokerage operation, the country's second largest.
Broad Advance for Stocks The Dow gained 26.87 points, to 10,714.82; the Nasdaq rose 48.33 points, to 3,845.74; and the S.& P. 500 edged up 8.19 points, to 1,478.73.

Antitrust Lawyer to Aid Napster The Internet music company, fighting the recording industry over copyrights, hired David Boies, special counsel to the Justice Department in the Microsoft antitrust case.
